Package gov.gsa.pivconformance.conformancelib.utilities

Class Validator

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.gsa.pivconformance.conformancelib.utilities.Validator
  • public class Validator
extends java.lang.Object
    Provides the API to validating a given end entity certificate for given certificate policy. 
    
 In  October 2020 the Federal Government created a new
 FPKI Root CA. he new root is named the Federal Common Policy CA G2 (FCPCAG 2)
 This new CA has issued new certificates to all CAs signed by the current
 FCPCA. This enables all current certificates issued by them to build a path to the new root
 What will be impacted?
 This change will affect all Federal agencies and will have an impact on the following services
 o Personal Identity Verification ( credential authentication to the government networks
 o Agency web applications implementing client authentication (e g PIV authentication)
 o User digital signatures that leverage PIV or similar credentials
 o Other applications leveraging the FCPCA as a root including Physical Access Control System (PACS) implementations
 When will this change take place?
 o Between now and May 2021 agencies will need to transition from using the old FCPCA as the root to the new FCPCG 2
 o Last week of January 2021 the new intermediate CA certificates must be published in CA repositories
 o February 2 2021 the FPKIMA team will migrate the FBCAG 4 to the FCPCAG 2 by publishing the cross certificate from the FCPCAG 2 to the FBCAG 4 and removing the cross certificates between the FBCAG 4 and the old FCPCA
 o May 2021 the FPKIMA team will decommission the old FCPCA
    Validator can be used to build a certificate path to an end-entity (EE) certificate. By default, the trust anchor is extracted from the keystore file cacerts.jks, based on the EE distinguished name. ICAM test card common names include the string "ICAM." All other certs are validated to FCPCA G2. If a trust anchor is supplied, the keystore is not used.

      • setCertPathBuilder

        public void setCertPathBuilder​(java.lang.String providerString)
        Sets the provider for crypto and certificate path validation. If providerString is "SunRsaSign" AIA downloading and timeouts is available. If providerString is "BC" then the BouncyCastle crypto libraries are used. If providerString is any other value NoSuchProviderException is thrown.
        Parameters:
        providerString - provider stringn

      • setProvider

        public void setProvider​(java.lang.String providerString)
        Sets the provider string which is used *later* as follows: If providerString is "SunRsaSign" AIA downloading and timeouts is available. If providerString is "BC" then the BouncyCastle crypto libraries will be used.
        Parameters:
        providerString - provider string

      • getProvider

        public java.lang.String getProvider()

      • getCertPathBuilder

        public java.security.cert.CertPathBuilder getCertPathBuilder()

      • setCaPathString

        public void setCaPathString​(java.lang.String path)
        Sets the URL/directory name where intermediate certificate bundles are found and used to augment the trust anchor keystore. If caPath starts with "https://", the string is used as a URL to download a file and caFile is used as the local file's destination for downloading. If caPath starts with "file://", it is treated as a local directory name to which caFile is appended to create a full path.
        Parameters:
        path - the URL/directory name

      • getCaPathString

        public java.lang.String getCaPathString()
        Gets the URL/directory name where intermediate certificate bundles are found and used to augment the trust anchor keystore. If caPath starts with "https://", the string is used as a URL to download a file and caFile is used as the local file's destination for downloading. If caPath starts with "file://", it is treated as a local directory name to which caFile is appended to create a full path.
        Returns:
        the URL/directory name

        public java.lang.String getResourceDir()

        Returns:
        URL/directory where resources are found

      • isValid

        public boolean isValid​(java.lang.String endEntityCertFile,
                       java.lang.String policyOids,
                       java.lang.String trustAnchorFile)
                throws ConformanceTestException
        Determines if a valid certificate path can be built to the specified trust anchor using the given policy OIDs
        Parameters:
        endEntityCertFile - string with file name of end entity cert
        policyOids - comma-separated string of policy OIDs
        trustAnchorFile - string with file name of trust anchor cert
        Returns:
        true if the certificate path was built, false if a path cannot be built
        Throws:
        java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException
        java.security.cert.CertStoreException
        java.security.cert.CertPathBuilderException
        java.security.InvalidAlgorithmParameterException
        java.security.NoSuchProviderException
        ConformanceTestException

      • isValid

        public boolean isValid​(java.io.File endEntityCertFile,
                       java.lang.String policyOids,
                       java.io.File trustAnchorCertFile)
                throws ConformanceTestException
        Determines if a valid certificate path can be built to the specified trust anchor using the given policy OIDs. If trustAnchorCertFile is null, resourceDir + /x509-certs/cacerts.jks is consulted for the appropriate trust anchor.
        Parameters:
        endEntityCertFile - file containing end entity cert
        policyOids - comma-separated string of policy OIDs
        trustAnchorCertFile - file containing trust anchor cert
        Returns:
        true if the certificate path was built, false if a path cannot be built
        Throws:
        java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException
        java.security.cert.CertStoreException
        java.security.cert.CertPathBuilderException
        java.security.InvalidAlgorithmParameterException
        java.security.NoSuchProviderException
        ConformanceTestException

      • isValid

        public boolean isValid​(java.security.cert.X509Certificate eeCert,
                       java.lang.String policyOids,
                       java.security.cert.X509Certificate trustAnchorCert)
                throws java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException,
                       java.security.cert.CertStoreException,
                       java.security.cert.CertPathBuilderException,
                       java.security.InvalidAlgorithmParameterException,
                       java.security.NoSuchProviderException,
                       ConformanceTestException
        Determines if a valid certificate path can be built to the specified trust anchor using the given policy OIDs
        Parameters:
        eeCert - X509Certificate end entity cert
        policyOids - comma-separated string of policy OIDs
        trustAnchorCert - X509Certificate trust anchor cert
        Returns:
        true if the certificate path was built, false if a path cannot be built
        Throws:
        java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException
        java.security.cert.CertStoreException
        java.security.cert.CertPathBuilderException
        java.security.InvalidAlgorithmParameterException
        java.security.NoSuchProviderException
        ConformanceTestException
